fields.attribution: The project is lead by Dr. Zeray Alemseged of the California Academy of Sciences. Core DRP team members include: Zeresenay Alemseged, René Bobe, Denis Geraads, Shannon McPherron, Denné Reed, and  Jonathan Wynn. Andrew Barr and Zelalem Bedaso participated in fieldwork as graduate students.
fields.abstract:
The Dikika Research Project (DRP) studies Pliocene hominins and paleoenvironments in the Afar Region of northeastern Ethiopia. 

Dikika is best known for the 3.3Ma juvenile Australopithecus afarensis fossil known as "Selam". Selam is the most complete fossil skeleton of this species and one of just a handful of juvenile hominin fossil skeletons known.

fields.attribution: The project is lead by Dr. Zeray Alemseged of the California Academy of Sciences.
fields.abstract: The Mille-Logya Research Project (MLP) is a paleoanthropological research effort located in northeastern Ethiopia, just a few kilometers north of Hadar and Dikika. The project was initiated in 2014.

fields.attribution: These data have previously been made available by the ETE program at the Smithsonian Institute.
fields.abstract: The Turkana Database contains information on fossil collections from the Turkana Basin in northern Kenya.

fields.attribution: The West Turkana project is coordinated by Carol Ward
fields.abstract: The West Turkana paleoanthropological research project includes fossil sites on the west shore of Lake Turkana such as Lomekwi and Kanapoi.

fields.attribution: This project was created by the PaleoCore development team: Denné Reed, Tomislav Urban, Andrew Barr, Shannon McPherron, Andrew Cook, Nick Pereira, Jeannette Tang.
fields.abstract: The San Francisco project is a public demonstration database introduced for the 2015 meeting of the Paleoanthropology Society in San Francisco. The data set uses the same structure as the Mille-Logya project but with example data records.
